title: The Hakucho [CORSA-B] Satellite
name: The Hakucho [CORSA-B] Satellite
descript: Corsa-B was the first X-ray astronomy Japanese satellite. Launched on 21 February 1979, it was renamed Hakucho (Japanese for “swan”) symbolizing one of the most interesting X-ray objects, Cyg X-1. As many other X-ray satellite launched in that period, Hakucho was designed to study and monitor transient phenomena with particular emphasis on X-ray bursts. It was still operating when the second X-ray Japanese satellite Tenma launched in 1983.

instruments.name: Very Soft X-ray experiment (VSX)
instruments.descript: Four identical proportional counters with a thin polypropylene window. Two of counters (P) were located in a direction almost parallel to the spin axis at 2.7° offset. The other two (V) where located offset to the spin axis tilted 45°.

instruments.name: Soft X-ray experiment (SFX)
instruments.descript: SFX consisted in 6 proportional counters with a Be window. Four of the counters (P divided in two CMC and two FMC) have a viewing direction parallel to the spin axis and the other two (V) were 45° tilted.

instruments.name: Hard X-ray experiment (HDX)
instruments.descript: HDX was a single NaI(Tl) scintillation counter located parallel to the spin axis with a small offset of 3°.

instrument_postscript: The instrument could be operated with different modes providing different energy and time resolution (with 5.86 ms minimum).
highlights: Discovery of soft X-ray transient Cen X-4 and Aql X-1
Long-term monitoring of X-ray pulsar (e.g. Vela X-1)
Discovery of 2 Hz variability in the Rapid Burster later named Quasi Period Oscillation
archive: No data is available at the HEASARC
